Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Volunteering and Democratization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1409243
Thomas Janoski
Sara R. Compion
University of Kentucky

The research addresses a significant gap in knowledge concerning volunteering in emerging democracies, by contributing an African-centered, sociological perspective to theories of civil society. The co-PI will employ a sociological approach and the notion of civic capital to study how associational volunteering shapes and is being shaped by democratization. The researcher will use a mixed-method, cross-national comparative approach to study domestic volunteering in 20 democratizing African countries. First, the study will identify a profile of Africans who actively belong to volunteer organizations. Next it contextualizes volunteering as a function of the varying civic and economic climates in which these individuals live. This is done through a multi-level statistical analysis of the 2008 Afrobarometer survey data. Finally, ethnographic case studies in South Africa and Zambia will be completed to analyze how cultural repertoires, values, and identity shape notions of democratic citizenship and inform volunteering behavior from the bottom up.

Findings from this research will identify the types and characteristics of people who actively join associational volunteer organizations in 20 African countries. The quantitative models will reveal if democratic advancement facilitates individual volunteering. The qualitative case studies will offer explanations about why and how people volunteer, and if their volunteering builds their civic capital which in turn fosters democracy.

Broader Impacts

Research findings will contribute to our understanding of how the deeply intertwined relationship between associational volunteering and democracy unfolds within developing and democratizing contexts. Results will have broader scholarly potential by contributing to comparative, quantitative analysis of African countries that increases the generalizability of existing theories on civil society to countries beyond the West. The findings can direct future efforts dedicated to maximizing the civic action of volunteering populations, and building targeted strategies for encouraging and recruiting those who are not yet civically engaged. State planners can use the evidence from this study to direct foreign aid towards those volunteer activities that increase the civic capital necessary for democratic nation building. Finally, non-profit organizations can benefit from the best-case scenarios on how to make their organizations more democratic, participatory, and civically oriented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sara Compion, under the supervision of Professor Thomas Janoski, has completed research for her dissertation titled, “Volunteering and Democratization in Transitioning Contexts of sub-Saharan Africa” supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. This dissertation research is about how southern Africans are dealing with rapid social change through their voluntary involvement in associational organizations and community groups.

Methodologically, it is a cross-national comparative study of volunteering and voluntary association membership in Africa. Research included a quantitative statistical project, combined with ethnographic comparisons of two southern African cities. The mixed method design allowed for linking people’s everyday experience of volunteering to the national socio-political landscape, thus demonstrating ways in which they negotiate and shape the relationship between volunteering and change. Data collection and analysis were broken down into two research projects: project 1) Statistical analysis of the Round 4 Afrobarometer survey data covering 20 sub-Saharan African countries; and project 2) Ethnographic fieldwork in Pretoria, South Africa and Lusaka, Zambia with qualitative data analysis. NSF funding was used to support the second research project.

First, statistical analyses of the Afrobarometer data outline a profile of Africans who actively belong to volunteer organizations and community groups, and contextualizes their activity as a function of the varying political and economic climates in which they live. The results show that being an active member of a voluntary association (not just being a member in name only) has a significant impact on democratic attitudes, interpersonal trust, and voting. While these are important aspects of a strong public sphere and civil society multilevel logistic models reveal that determinates of active voluntary association membership lie mostly in possessing a civic ethos and in having established social capital. In these African countries, development aid features strongly in fostering a context for associational activity. Moreover, the relationship between volunteering and democracy – so prominent in Western country contexts – is not evident. This could be attributed to the conflict ridden realms of class, ethnicity and religion in the murkiness of Africa’s “civic” sphere.

Second, ethnographic fieldwork included interviews and focus groups with volunteers as well as nonprofit and voluntary organization leaders, and collecting documents related to the history and context of volunteering in these settings. The resulting qualitative findings are used to generate a contextual theory involving the performative differences of volunteers in the face of rapid urban social-structural changes. Drawing on the value-classification indices of both Geert Hofstede and Ronald Inglehart, this study shows that participants’ values can be conceived of as “allegiant,” “opportunistic,” and/or “alienated” toward national circumstance. Consequently, depending on their value-foundation participants gravitate toward volunteer activities that are aimed at either supporting and enhancing, challenging and confronting, or maintaining and preserving social systems. This cultural approach gives volunteers agency, while also showcasing the unique socioeconomic and political effect of the broader transitioning context.

The intellectual merit of this study lies in its ability to address a significant gap in knowledge concerning volunteering in transitioning contexts, and by contributing an African-centered, sociological perspective to theories of civil society in times of flux.
